description: Examination of the marketing aspects of products or services exclusive of their promotion, pricing or distribution. Focuses on decisions regarding product introduction, positioning, improvements, and deletion, and the tools available for making these decisions.
name: NEW PRODUCT MANAGEMENT

values.comments:
This course is an examination of the marketing aspects of products. It provides a total immersion in the new product development process. Material focuses on decisions regarding product introduction, positioning, improvements, deletion, and the tools available for making these decisions. 

Students mentioned that this course was interesting, but moved very fast since it was only half a semester. 

Students found Professor Adams to be “funny,” “enthusiastic,” and passionate about the material. Many mentioned that lectures and the overall structure of the course was somewhat disorganized. Finally, a few mentioned that the professor “gives very vague answers and sometimes doesn't answer your question.” 

Regarding the course work, some elements include a group project, writing assignments, and readings. A few students mentioned that there were “too many readings/concepts that you don't get to fully discuss.” The group project counts for a significant portion of the grade (50%).

This course is an examination of the marketing aspects of products. It provides a total immersion in the new product development process. Material focuses on decisions regarding product introduction, positioning, improvements, deletion, and the tools available for making these decisions. 

In this course the main focus was on “techniques and some research studies.” Some students found this material “eye opening.” Others, however, found that they “learned very little about new product management.” Many students would have preferred more practical applications. 

A number of students found Professor Armstrong’s teaching ability to be outstanding. Many mentioned, though, that he does not “provide clear outlines of what he expects for case analyses or projects,” leaving groups directionless. Furthermore, many felt that he introduced his own political views and “occasionally controversial ideas” in class. 

The course, being only five class sessions long, felt rushed to many students. Eighty percent of the class grade was based on a final exam, presentation, and report. Many found the exam difficult and did not agree with some of the grading procedures. Finally, weekly assignments are given but ungraded.
